awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns number theory. It focuses on automorphic forms---functions that are invariant under a large discrete group of symmetries.  When the order of applying the symmetries does not matter, such functions may be studied by Fourier analysis, discovered in the nineteenth century; however, for more complicated symmetries new ideas are needed and our knowledge is far from complete. The fundamental Langlands Functoriality Conjectures predict that highly symmetric functions are the keys to understanding solutions to polynomial equations, making a bridge between the continuous (functions) and the discrete (solutions). A specific case of the conjectures played a key role in Wiles's proof of Fermat's Conjecture, but most cases of the Langlands Conjectures are still unproved. This project will provide new information about automorphic forms, including functoriality, and about quantities in number theory and in other areas of mathematics related to automorphic forms.

In more detail, this project includes problems related to functoriality, L-functions, and covering groups. In one series of problems, the principal investigator proposes to give applications of, and to generalize, a new recent construction, the twisted doubling integral, which makes it possible to analyze L-functions for non-generic automorphic forms. A second series of problems concerns automorphic forms on general covering groups, the metaplectic groups. The principal investigator proposes to give broad examples of the principle that constructions involving automorphic forms on linear groups (or the double covers described by Weil) can be extended to general covering groups. A third set of problems concerns new constructions involving automorphic forms, representation theory, and number theory, including the study of functionals on p-adic groups related to Iwahori-Hecke algebras and quantum groups. This research will advance our knowledge of automorphic forms on reductive groups and their covers, with consequences for number theory, representation theory, and string theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Langlands Program envisions deep connections ("functoriality") between harmonic analysis on different groups, connections which are tied to number theory. The PI and his collaborators Cai and Kaplan, building on earlier joint work with Ginzburg, have established a new instance of Langlands functoriality lifting cuspidal automorphic representations on generalized Spin groups to general linear groups. To do so, they employ the converse theorem and treat the needed Rankin-Selberg L-functions by means of new generalized doubling integrals.

Anotther kind of correspondence that has been studied for many years is the theta correspondence. This correspondence is based on the oscillator represnetation, and it is often, but not always, functorial. The PI and his collaborator Ginzburg have introduced a new theta correspondence for metaplectic covers that is based on the tensor product of two theta representations.  All prior theta correspondences had used a single theta, so this construction is surprising. He and Ginzburg have also studied the unramfiied local correspondence and the Whittaker range of the lift.

A third project, joint with Offen, concerns generalizations of the Shimura correspondence, which is another map between automorphic objects with great number theoretic significance.  They establish the Fundamental Lemma for a new relative trace formula.  Though much remains to be done, in prior trace formulas this was a key obstacle and so establishing it is of significance. When this formula is developed in full, it will give a new, previously unknown, Shimura map for automorphic forms on the cubic cover of SL(3).

During this period, the PI has also advised several graduate students, one of whom finished his PhD in December 2022, and he has given numerous lectures at universities and conferences. He is one of the organizers of the 8-week program on New Connections in Number Theory and Physics taking place in August and September 2022 at the Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences, Cambridge, England, and he was one of the organizers for an on-line workshop on this topic in 2021. 

During the period of this grant, the principal investigator served on the Committee on the Profession for both the Mathematics Association of America and the American Mathematical Society, and as Vice Chair and then Chair of the U.S. National Commission on Mathematics Instruction, the US adhering body to the International Commission on Mathematics Instruction; he currently also serves as the US representative to this body.  The PI was also one of the participants in A Roundtable Discussion on Math Education in the U.S. at the National Museum of Mathematics, July 2021, and he works with teachers and contributes to policy discussions on math eduation, providing the perspective of a highly active scholar of mathematics who is also knowledgable about issues in K-12 math education.
